children.subject: Just a heads up, according to Data 100's FAQ (http://www.ds100.org/fa18faq), you can choose to have attendance not count towards your grade.

Thanks so much for the advice! I'm actually also enrolled in 194 already (used my phase 1 on it and 160 so I'd be able to make the choice later), so it would probably be advantageous for me to drop it later if I decide not to take it. I've also already enrolled in my upper div social science course (Global 173); it's for my minor.

Sounds good. I'll say this, if you haven't taken 70 you're going to have a tough time in 31. The textbook covers all of 70 in a weeks worth of chapters and then covers a ton more on graphs and game theory. While Friedman posted incredibly light prereqs, you'd definitely want that. Likewise, the course is mostly for academic work in social networking -- if that appeals to you definitely take it, but it's definitely more operations research than anything software engineering.

CS 194's prof, Eric Friedman, has historically taught CS 174. I personally think he's really cool, and the 194-31 course is adapted from a very popular Cornell course, where Friedman used to teach. That said please don't enroll I'm on the waitlist and it's the only course I want to take :\. He's an IEOR prof who did Physics research for a while, and now is a lead researcher at ICSI on traditional OR-compute problems like market dynamics and the Travelling Salesman, as well as medical imaging 

Data 100 is fun too btw. As others noted, attendance isn't a major thing. However, between 160 and Data 100, there'd be some projects that would conflict and make your life super hard. Overall, having taken Data 100, I know it's a very good course, especially as it would get you hired to be a real data scientist [or intern somewhere], and Josh Hug is perfectly suited to the course, which already has some extremely interesting lectures [that you should watch now on coursecapture.berkeley.edu] and it's considered good prep for CS 189 and working at the RISELab. 160 has some good applications, but Eric Paulos and Bjorn Hartmann will work with you if you haven't taken the course [source, have worked with both of them]. CS 194-31 is based on this networking textbook, which is also used in Demography 180 'Social Networks', a 3 unit course which might actually count as your upper div social science course so do that instead because I really like Friedman and want to take a course with him before I graduate.

IMO, your most time-efficient schedule would be 70/16B/Demo 180/CS c100 and after dying several times over because three of those classes are brutal though Demo 180 has a good grade distribution, join Eric Paulos' hybrid ecologies lab [which will do more for a resume for frontend work than 160, IMO] and try and get some paper authorship as that lab consistently does extremely well at conferences.

history.content:
I think it would be better to get all of the fundamentals out of the way, both for the sake of internships and to build prerequisite knowledge for future classes. Take 61C instead of those classes. There is no EECS requirement that mandates you take any upper divs your sophomore year. If you hate the thought of doing low-level coding or think that's too much work, I would advise you to do 53 if you haven't already, because 53 actually helps significantly with 70 since you will be integrating joint distributions.

Also, have you taken 16A? EECS majors CANNOT replace that class with 54.

Other good options would be Physics 7A/B.

Data 100 is not really meant for EECS majors; from what I hear it's too watered down to be useful. Also, the grading is a bit screwy because everyone does so well, so the class tends to be curved down.

CS160 is not a terribly useful class unless UI/UX is something you really want to do.

CS194 is a special topics class, and those tend to be hit or miss.

children.subject: No, 47D is only meant as a conceptual connector for 16B for L&S students. EECS must take 16A.
Unfortunately, you have to do 16A. 54 + 7B does not replace this requirement for EECS. You probably will not learn anything new, but you still have to take it.

history.content:
Hello friends! I'm an EECS major/incoming sophomore and I wanted some advice on which upper division class I should take next semester.

As of now, I know for sure that I'll be taking CS70, EE16B, and an upper-division social sciences class. I've taken 61A/B, Math 54, and Data 8 so far in terms of ~potentially~ relevant courses.

The courses I'm considering for my fourth course are:

-CS160 (currently enrolled)--I like HCI a lot but I don't really like frontend and it's not something that I'm looking for internships in, so I'm conflicted about this class. I'm also afraid that it might be too much of a time commitment? (although any upper division class probably is). At a really good time IMO.

-CS194 (the networks one; also currently enrolled)--it seems super interesting! but the timings aren't great (I prefer earlier classes) and I haven't heard much about the professor?

-Data100--I'd love to take Data 100!! And Hug is teaching which makes it even greater. But let's be real--I likely wouldn't attend lecture since it's so late in the evening; I have a club meeting during lectures one of the days. Idk if lecture is going to be mandatory for it either?

(edited to remove CS186 since lecture would conflict with EE16B ://)

Any advice would be nice & thank you!! 

EDIT: I've taken the equivalent of 53 and 7A as well as 7B. I'm done with literally every lower div but 16B, 16A (which I was under the impression that 54 + 7B + a little bit of outside studying fulfilled), 70, and 61C. I have a feeling that 16B + 70 + 61C might be a bit much. I just figured 53/7B/7A weren't likely to be useful in terms of prior knowledge for the classes I'm considering so I didn't list them above.
history.subject: Class Advice!

history.content:
Hello friends! I'm an EECS major/incoming sophomore and I wanted some advice on which upper division class I should take next semester.

As of now, I know for sure that I'll be taking CS70, EE16B, and an upper-division social sciences class. I've taken 61A/B, Math 54, and Data 8 so far in terms of ~potentially~ relevant courses.

The courses I'm considering for my fourth course are:

-CS160 (currently enrolled)--I like HCI a lot but I don't really like frontend and it's not something that I'm looking for internships in, so I'm conflicted about this class. I'm also afraid that it might be too much of a time commitment? (although any upper division class probably is).

-CS194 (the networks one; also currently enrolled)--it seems super interesting! but the timings aren't great (I prefer earlier classes) and I haven't heard much about the professor?

-Data100--I'd love to take Data 100!! And Hug is teaching which makes it even greater. But let's be real--I likely wouldn't attend lecture since it's so late in the evening; I have a club meeting during lectures one of the days. Idk if lecture is going to be mandatory for it either?

-CS186--so I haven't taken CS61C yet, which I know is one of the prereqs (how important is it to the class? and will I get booted if I don't have the prereq completed?), but looking at the syllabus, this is a lot of what I'm doing for my internship right now (albeit in Java) and I think it would be very useful in that sense? However, it is at the same time as EE16B so I'm not sure if I'd attend lecture (although ngl I don't attend lecture for most of my classes?)

Any advice would be nice & thank you!!
